title: Can you get hacked by answering a text? - Quora

response.answer_text: Not really, it depends what information you give them. If you open a link, they will immediately know your IP address because everyone has an internet IP address and you could see it…. if you were using your home WiFi internet, then they can know your home address with your IP address. If you fell for a phishing scam and got tricked and type in your passwords, then it's too late and they have your password, you must immediately change all your passwords right away. Sometimes people get greedy and they fall for phishing scams.. responding to messages like “you won a free iPad! Please enter your information to claim it!”. Or sometimes they pretend that you got hacked and you must log in to your account to resolve the issue but it's actually a fake login page and they steal your passwords. If you click the link and installed some app on your phone, then that will make you vulnerable to hacking… but other than that, simply responding to a text won't get you hacked.. it will however confirm that your phone number is active and then they may begin sending you spam messages and calls, so never ever respond to a spam text or email, you are only going to confirm your subscription. There are many people saying “iOS is more secure than Android!” Well newsflash, the iOS software in recent times was proven to have a big security loophole through the keyboard.. any app could basically read your keyboard data and this was the whole reason why TikTok got the blame for it. So just because you have an iPhone, don't assume you're untouchable.. Here it is, read for yourself: Security demo reminds iOS users that any app (or widget) can read the clipboard silently - 9to5Mac iOS 14 reveals clipboard snooping is far worse than we thought

Ooooh, finally an interesting question! Well, it depends if you are on iOS or Andriod. iOS has a reputation for having great malware* protection and defense (*malicious software, “getting hacked” in one word), though iOS has had its own glitches. Apple does take iMessage pretty seriously, so you would have to be dealing with some smartass hackers. On the other hand, if you click on the link that they sent you at three in the morning with the caption “good porn trust me,” you can bet your ass your iPhone is gonna be loaded with Malware. On Andriod, you can probably count on being less safe. Maybe get an antivirus or two, especially with Play Store’s reputation. You can probably (definitely) get hacked just by looking at a text, as long as the hacker is advanced enough and the app you’re using is crappy enough and you’re not using SMS or MMS. Conclusion: Yeah, you can get hacked just by opening a text. But the circumstances under which you would get hacked are so absurd, that there is practically no threat. Hope this helped!

No, but if the text is a scam text, you will confirm to the person or system on the other end that your number is “live.” This means that they now know a potential victim is at that number. Only reply to texts from people you know.
